sen.j: 負所（おっしょ）とは、中世の荘園において、本来は国衙に納めるべき雑役（場合によっては官物の一部を含む）を免除を受け、その分を自己に収めることが出来る荘園領主及びその土地を指す。
sen.e: The term "Ossho" means the lords of Shoen (manor in medieval Japan) who were exempted from and allowed to get Zatsueki (a kind tax under the Ritsuryo system) (sometimes inclusive of the portion of Kanmotsu (tribute goods)) supposed to be paid to Kokuga (provincial government offices) as well as the land of such Shoen.

sen.j: 元来、朝廷や皇族の所有地であったものが寺院などに寄進されて荘園化されたものが多い。
sen.e: Many of Ossho were the former territory of the Imperial Court or Iimperial family which became Shoen after being donated to temples etc.

sen.j: 本来こうした荘園の取り分である雑役が国衙が官物とともに一括徴収していたが、負所では荘園領主に直接納入された。
sen.e: Zatsueki gained from such Shoen was originally collected by Kokuga together with Kanmotsu, but in the case of Ossho, it was directly delivered to the lords of Shoen.

sen.j: 本来は実際にこれを耕作していた負人（ふにん）側からの呼び名であると言われている。
sen.e: It is said that this name was originally used by funin, people who actually cultivated Ossho).

sen.j: ただし、負所の荘園領主は不作の年でも一定の得分を確保する特権を有する代わりに得分そのものが反別一斗程度と低く、下地支配権を持たなかった。
sen.e: However, while the lords of such Shoen had the privilage to gain a pre-fixed profit even in the year of poor harvest, such pre-fixed profit was low, itto (about 18L) per tan (an are), and they didn't have shitaji-shihaiken (the right to rule the land).

sen.j: そこで荘園領主は現地の名主と結びついて一円支配の確立に努めた。
sen.e: Under such circumstances, lords of Shoen strived for the establishment of ichien-shihai (complete rule over people and land of Shoen) in collusion with local myoshu (owner of rice fields).
